text: So again, how would you say I have eaten?
J'ai mangé.
How do you think you'd say I have eaten it?
Je l'ai mangé.
So, I have is...
J'ai.
But I have is actually made out up of two components, the I and the have.
If you said them separately, they would be pronounced as...
Je ai.
So when you say I have eaten it, of course the have steals the pronoun
and puts it directly in front of itself,
which again splits these abbreviated I have back into its component parts,
into I have.
And again, I have when split is...
Je ai.
So, again, how would you say I have eaten it?
Je l'ai mangé.
How would you say I did eat it?
Je l'ai mangé.
Again, you may remember from earlier in the course where I pointed out that in French in the past,
they use fewer tenses than we do.
Where we might say I ate it, I did eat it, I have eaten it.
You typically only say I have eaten it.
This makes it far easier for us.
Let's try another example.
How would you say I have prepared it?
Je l'ai préparé.
Je l'ai préparé.
How would you say I prepared it?
Je l'ai préparé.
And I did prepare it.
Je l'ai préparé.
Again, all of these sentences in French are the same.
How about you have sold it?
You l'avez vendu.
Using a rising intonation, how would you turn it into a question and say you've sold it?
You l'avez vendu?
Again, using a rising intonation, how would you ask the question, did you sell it?
You l'avez vendu?
As I said earlier, these tenses such as you have sold it, you did sell it, you sold it, are the same in French.
They'll simply be expressed as you have sold it.
And as you've just seen, the same applies for a question.
Have you sold it in French?
And did you sell it?
Will both be translated in the same way.
Which makes your job easier.
As you don't need to worry about switching tenses.
In the same way we would in English.
For the past tense, it's simply not quite as hard in French.
In English.
Thank you.
